message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient was bitten by a cat, indicating a risk of infection with Pasteurella multocida. Amoxicillin-clavulanate is the first-line antibiotic prophylaxis for animal bites. Surgical debridement is only necessary for infected wounds. Laceration closure is not recommended until the wound is clean and infection-free.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a deep puncture wound from a cat bite, which increases the risk of infection due to bacteria in the cat’s mouth. Therefore, prophylactic antibiotics are recommended. Amoxicillin-clavulanate is the drug of choice. Surgical debridement and closure of the wound should be considered if the wound is extensive or there is evidence of deep infection. In this case, the wound is actively bleeding but there is no mention of extensive or deep involvement, therefore, laceration closure is not necessary.

Surgical debridement is only necessary if there is evidence of extensive tissue damage or infection.
